description: Display of 1no.x internally illuminated Facia sign,  1no.x internally illuminated projecting/hanging sign and 3no.x non illuminated other signage.
decision_conditions: Any structure or hoarding erected or used principally for the purpose of displaying advertisements shall be maintained in a condition that does not endanger the public.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any advertisement displayed, and any site used for the display of advertisements, shall be maintained in a condition that does not impair the visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

This consent shall be restricted to a period of five years from the date of the consent.Reason: This condition is specified by the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

Where an advertisement is required under these Regulations to be removed, the site shall be left in a condition that does not endanger the public or impair visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007

No advertisement to be displayed without the permission of the owner of the site or any other person with an interest in the site entitled to grant permission.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The sign permitted by this consent shall only be illuminated during the opening hours of the premises to which it relates.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

The intensity of the illumination of the lighting permitted by this consent shall be no greater than 400 cd/m. Reason: In the interests of amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Consultations21no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the demolition of the existing detached garage and WC and erection of single-storey rear extension and conversion of existing attached garage to habitable space and open yard.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey, semi-detached property. The surrounding properties comprise of predominantly semi-detached and detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; and-	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained behind the existing built form. The proposals involve the demolition of the existing detached rear garage building and WC and conservatory and replacement erection of a single storey rear extension.  The application also seeks permission for the conversion of the existing attached garage to habitable accommodation. To the side a passageway would be proposed to allow independent through access to the rear garden.The rear extension is proposed to have a flat roof with two similar sized projecting roof lanterns. The extension would be part 4.5m and part 7.7m in depth and would span the full width of the dwellinghouse. The proposed extension is considered appropriate in its scale and appropriate in its design, in keeping with the host building. Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed rear single-storey extension would cause no significant increase in the loss of privacy, loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties. Officers note that the maximum projection is at an inset of approximately 3.8m from the adjoining neighbour (No. 4).Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

Any upper-floor window located in a wall or roof slope forming a side elevation of thedwellinghouse must be—(i) obscure-glazed, and(ii) non-opening unless the parts of the window which can be opened are more than 1.7metres above the floor of the room in which the window is installedThe application states that internal blinds will be used but this does not meet the requirements of the legislation.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. It is noted that application ref: 22/02589/CLC was refused for the following reason:The Privacy Screens along the northern and southern edges of the terraces would not be constructed so that they are 1.7m above finished floor level and constructed from obscure glazing. Therefore, failing to preserve the of privacy of the occupants of neighbouring land and buildings.It is considered that the applicant has now provided sufficient information to demonstrate that the Privacy Screens along the northern and southern edges of the terraces would be constructed so that they are 1.7m above finished floor level and constructed from obscure glazing.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultees and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 16 (Screening of Terrace/Balcony Areas) of planning permission 19/02482/FUL, which states:Condition 16 (Screening of Terrace/Balcony Areas) -  Prior to the commencement of any relevant work, a scheme for the screening of the terrace/balcony areas of the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The measures contained in the approved scheme shall then be implemented in full prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
The declaration section in the application form is signed by a different person, please amend the application form with the correct names.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Demolition of an existing rear conservatory, erection of part two storey/part single storey side, single storey rear and front porch extension. Erection of boundary wall and fence.'
